awd_titl_txt: RUI: Thermodynamics of Nucleation: Atmospheric Aerosols from Acids, Bases, and Peptides
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor George Shields of Furman University is supported by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Atmospheric Chemistry Program of the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences. The goal of the project is to examine properties of molecular complexes in the atmosphere.  These molecules are formed from water molecules, sulfuric acid molecules, and other trace molecules.  Such molecules are important because they are fundamental to how particles, and from these, clouds, form. The mechanism for the start of cloud formation is currently not well-understood. Undergraduate students carry out the research and gain experience in chemical modeling for several years. The team includes female students and students from underrepresented minorities. A post-doctoral associate participates in the research and the mentoring of the undergraduate students. Professor Shields has a long-standing collaboration with researchers working with undergraduate research groups, known as MERCURY. Historically, about half of the undergraduate students from these cohorts attend graduate school.
 
The quantum chemical calculations determine the minimum energy structures, thermodynamics for formation, and relative abundance of molecular clusters. Clusters that serve as neutral and ionic cloud condensation nuclei contain acids, bases, and water. The acids considered are sulfuric acid, formic acid, and amino acids. The bases include ammonia and amines. The work combines a genetic algorithm for configurational sampling with efficient high-level quantum chemical methods that have been computationally expensive for systems of this size until now. The calculated trends in thermodynamics of cluster formation are compared with experimental nucleation rates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project was to apply computational chemistry methods to model the formation of atmospheric aerosols and water clusters at a molecular level. These complexes are formed from water molecules, sulfuric acid molecules, and other trace molecules found in the atmosphere. These complexes are important because aerosols are essential for cloud formation, and the mechanism for how clouds begin to form from aerosols is currently not known. This is incredibly important because how aerosols form and make clouds is one of the major uncertainties in the models that predict global warming. Understanding how aerosols form has the potential to benefit society since aerosols can possibly slow down the rate of global warming. Sulfates have the largest cooling effect among aerosols and the presence of sulfuric acid has been shown to strongly correlate with aerosol formation. We have advanced the knowledge of how small molecules such as sulfuric acid, bases, and water form small clusters in the atmosphere. Our exploration of different acid/base combinations has revealed that the details of hydrogen bond topology are often more important than acid/base strength, which means that chemical intuition based on liquids is of limited use for understanding which gas-phase prenucleation form from a handful of different precursor molecules. We have established a high-level computational method, based on highly accurate quantum chemistry, that allows us to determine the structures of small aerosols that are most likely to be found in the atmosphere under specific conditions of concentrations of different molecules and the temperature.

During this project I have worked with 23 undergraduates and a postdoctoral associate. Sixteen of the undergraduates are female, and six are Black/African-American, and overall 17/23, or 74%, of the students working on this project were diverse. In addition, the postdoctoral associate is Asian-American. Both the education of undergraduates to understand the scientific method through significant research experiences, and the education of underrepresented students in chemistry are of great benefit to society and advance and improve societal outcomes. Eleven of the 22 undergraduates have graduated to date. Ten of these alumni are now in graduate school, and one is a high school science teacher. The 10 in graduate school are an African-American female in graduate school in Computational Neuroscience at Caltech, an African-American female in graduate school in Neuroscience at Harvard, a female in graduate school in Physics at Caltech, a female in graduate school in Theoretical Chemistry at Emory, a female in graduate school in Environmental Engineering at Arizona State, a female in graduate school in Environmental Systems at UNC Charlotte, a female in graduate school in Computational Chemistry at Furman University, a female in medical school at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, a male in graduate school in Computational Chemistry at the University of Tennessee, a male in graduate school in Computational Chemistry at Georgia Tech.
